stem: A 19-year-old client with DKA has received 6 liters of Normal Saline over the last 4 hours. Based on the documentation in the Serial DKA-Resuscitation & Pulmonary Sound Log, what is the most appropriate nursing intervention for the current findings?

tabs.title: Metabolic Trends
tabs.content:
Now: Glucose 320 mg/dL. pH 7.24. Potassium 3.8 mEq/L.
Condition: Ketosis is resolving; anion gap is narrowing.

tabs.title: Pulmonary Assessment
tabs.content:
IndicatorPre-TreatmentCurrent (After 6L)
Breath SoundsClearCrackles to midway up both lungs
SpO298%88% (on 2L nasal cannula)
Frothy SputumNoneNew pink-tinged sputum noted

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 158/92, HR 108. Client is sitting upright and appears anxious/struggling to breathe.

options.text: Decrease the IV fluid rate and prepare for diuretics/supplemental oxygen
Increase the IV fluid rate to 1,000 mL/hr to 'flush' the ketones
Switch the Ivy fluid from Normal Saline to 5% Dextrose only
Maintain the current course, as crackles are expected in DKA resolution

rationale.correct: This is **Iatrogenic Pulmonary Edema (a1)**. The client has received too much fluid (6 liters) too quickly, leading to volume overload. The crackles, low SpO2 (88%), and **pink-tinged frothy sputum** are classic indicators of pulmonary edema. Even though the DKA is getting better (ketones resolving), the nurse must **decrease the fluid rate (a1)** and address the respiratory failure immediately with oxygen and potentially diuretics (after checking K+).
clinicalPearls: In DKA, the 'empty tank' must be filled, but filling it too fast causes the heart to fail (edema) or the brain to swell (cerebral edema).
Lungs over Urine: Always prioritize breathing status even if the 'kidney' or 'metabolic' problem is the reason they were admitted.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never prioritize the 'Lab Fix' (ketones) over the 'Life Fix' (Breathing). If the lungs are full of fluid (crackles/88%), you STOP adding fluid.

mnemonic.title: Wet and Pink
mnemonic.expansion: Crackles (Wet). Frothy (Pink). Too much Saline. You're at the Brink.
